Amendment to section 2318 includes trafficking in counterfeit labels, illicit labels, or counterfeit documentation. SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability under certain sections of Title 17, United States Code, and do not apply to electronic transmissions of genuine or counterfeit documents under Title 18, United States Code. The amendments to Title 18, United States Code, pertain to electronic transmission of counterfeit labels or documentation. The fair use provision under Title 17, United States Code, remains unaffected by these amendments. TITLE II--FRAUDULENT ONLINE IDENTITY SANCTIONS

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as the ``Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act''.

SEC. 202. AMENDMENT TO TRADEMARK ACT OF 1946. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a new subsection (e) which establishes a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the violation. This does not limit what may be considered a willful violation under this section. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. This does not limit what may be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as in section 45 of the Act. The term 'domain name' is defined in section 45 of the Act entitled 'Trademark Act of 1946'. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Sec. 204 amends Section 3559 of title 18, U.S. Code to include a sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of felony offenses involving false registration and use of a domain name. The maximum imprisonment for such offenses will be doubled or increased by 7 years, whichever is less. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for defendants convicted of felony offenses carried out online using a domain name registered with materially false information. The Sentencing Commission will amend guidelines to enhance sentences for felony offenses committed online using false contact information for domain name registration. The Sentencing Commission will amend guidelines to enhance sentences for felony offenses involving false contact information for domain name registration. The term "domain name" is defined in section 45 of the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 205 of the title ensures that free speech and press rights are not affected by domain name registration activities. It also allows courts discretion in determining damages for intellectual property infringement and terms of imprisonment. In TITLE III, a court location in Colorado is added.
